fact: In Finland, there are more saunas than cars.
Bhutan measures its success by Gross National Happiness instead of GDP.
Mongolia has more horses than people.
In Bolivia, there are zebras—but they’re actually people dressed in costumes who help children cross streets safely.
Greenland has no roads connecting its towns; travel is mainly by boat, plane, or dog sled.
In Japan, there’s a train station that has no entrance or exit—it exists solely for passengers to enjoy the scenery when the train stops.
In Egypt, new desert cities are being built to reduce overcrowding in Cairo, including one with Africa’s tallest skyscraper.
Scotland has 421 words for snow, including 'sneesl' (to begin snowing) and 'skelf' (large snowflake).
Ethiopia uses a different calendar system, which is about seven years behind the Gregorian calendar.
In South Korea, there are special 'silent cafés' where customers are discouraged from talking to maintain complete quiet.
In Turkey, people drink more tea per person than anywhere else in the world, even more than in the UK.
Madagascar is home to over 90% of its wildlife species that are found nowhere else on Earth.
In Iceland, many people still believe in elves and hidden people; some construction projects are rerouted to avoid disturbing their supposed homes.
Singapore has a building shaped like a durian, the country's famously spiky-smelling fruit.
In India, there’s a temple where rats are worshipped and freely roam among the devotees.
Chile’s Atacama Desert is one of the driest places on Earth, yet flowers bloom across it once every few years in a rare event called 'desierto florido.'
In Sweden, people celebrate 'Fika'—a cultural practice of taking a daily coffee and pastry break, seen as a social necessity.
In Kenya, the Great Rift Valley is so large it can be seen from space and is slowly splitting the African continent in two.
The Philippines has the world’s largest underground river that flows directly into the sea.
In Norway, you can see the midnight sun in summer, where the sun doesn’t set for weeks above the Arctic Circle.
New Zealand was the first country to give women the right to vote, in 1893.
In Mexico, there’s an island filled with hundreds of dolls hanging from trees, believed to be haunted.
Liechtenstein is so small that its entire population could fit inside a single football stadium.
In Nigeria, Nollywood produces more films each year than Hollywood.
In Croatia, the necktie was invented and introduced to Europe by Croatian soldiers in the 17th century.
In Switzerland, it is illegal to own just one guinea pig because they get lonely.
In Canada, parts of Hudson Bay don’t have full gravity strength due to past glaciers pressing into the Earth’s crust.
In Portugal, there’s a tradition of walking across hot coals barefoot as a cultural ritual in some villages.
The Maldives is the flattest country in the world, with an average ground level of just 1.5 meters above sea level.
In Brazil, the Amazon River once flowed in the opposite direction, toward the Pacific Ocean.
In Germany, there are more than 1,500 types of sausages.
In Poland, a crooked forest exists where trees grow with a 90-degree bend at the base.
In Thailand, there is a festival where monkeys are given a buffet of food as a way to honor them.
In France, there’s a town named Y, making it the shortest place name in the world.
In Argentina, there’s a lake with petrified trees and fossilized remains from millions of years ago.
In Russia, Lake Baikal holds about 20% of the world’s unfrozen freshwater.
In South Africa, Table Mountain is home to more plant species than the entire United Kingdom.
In Ireland, Halloween originated as the ancient Celtic festival of Samhain.
In Cuba, old American cars from the 1950s are still widely used due to trade restrictions.
In Saudi Arabia, camels once outnumbered cars as the main mode of transportation.
In China, ice cream was invented around 200 BC, long before it appeared in Europe.
In Australia, wombats have cube-shaped poop to mark their territory.
In Austria, there’s a village named Fucking, which had to change its name in 2021 due to tourist theft of its signs.
In Spain, people participate in 'La Tomatina,' the world’s biggest food fight, using over 100 tons of tomatoes.
In Denmark, people throw cinnamon at anyone who remains unmarried on their 25th birthday.
In Jordan, the ancient city of Petra was carved entirely into rose-red cliffs over 2,000 years ago.
In Nepal, Mount Everest grows about 4 millimeters taller each year due to tectonic activity.
In Iran, the Lut Desert is one of the hottest places on Earth, with ground temperatures above 70°C recorded.
In Tanzania, Mount Kilimanjaro has glaciers at its summit despite being near the equator.
